page.title: 07History - from 9th Century
page.content: In the 9th century the May was used as a retreat by the missionary Adrian (Ethernan) and his followers for a few years. This ass ociation of St. Adrian with the May is of major importance. With his followers, St Adrian was based on the May and spent much of his life evangalising on the Fife coast. The Danes after devistating all of Britannia, landed on the Isle in March, 875 A.D. and St Adrian and his followers were martyred. Shortly before the middle of the 12th century King David I, who was responsible for setting up so many religeous houses and episcopal seats in Scotland, made a gift of the May and its fishings to the Abbey of Reading in Berkshire. The Priory of May remained with the monks of Reading for almost one and a quarter centuries.
